Award.AwardTitle: The Vertical Structure of Spiral Disks
Award.AbstractNarration: This project comprises an observational campaign to determine the mass distributions in the disks of large spiral galaxies, and thereby to constrain the importance of dark matter in the inner regions of these systems. The Principal Investigator has, with previous NSF support, led the development of special-purpose integral-field spectrographs (or integral-field units, IFUs) for mapping the motions of stars and gas in galaxies. With this instrumentation, he has recently completed the Diskmass Survey, acquiring multi-color broad-band imaging and integral-field rotation and velocity dispersion maps of galaxy disks oriented face-on to the line of sight. These data suggest that galaxy disks have lower mass-to-light ratios than expected, which implies that there is no large population of faint, very low-mass stars, and that dark-matter halos are dynamically important even in the galaxies' inner regions. However, the conclusions are weakened by uncertainties in the actual thicknesses of the disks along the line of sight. To remedy the situation, the Principal Investigator, his collaborators, and graduate students will conduct further observations, focusing on similar galaxies that are oriented edge-on to the line of sight. Specifically, they will (1) make photometric measurements of 20 galaxies, in strategically chosen wide and narrow infrared spectral bands that will permit the separation of stellar populations of different age; (2) make IFU measurements of the rotation speed and velocity dispersions in edge on disks, as functions of both distance from the galactic center and distance from the disk midplane, and then compare the rates of change of these quantities against dynamical models to constrain the gravitating mass distributions in the disk and the dark halo; and (3) re-examine the Diskmass Survey data to determine if earlier suggestions in one galaxy for systematic variation in stellar motions with age of the population are borne out in the entire sample. The broader impact of this project includes the launching of science programs on NSF-supported instrumentation, graduate student training and mentoring and inclusion of research results in undergraduate course development, and public presentations that disseminate results to a wide audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this program include the following six items that combine elements of intellectual merit and broader impact:

(1) We discovered the presence of significant super-thin disks of stars in spiral galaxies like the Milky Way (see images). This discovery changes our assumptions about how stellar mass is distributed within the disks of galaxies. In particular, it makes these disks more self-gravitating even if they contribute relatively little to overall dynamical mass of these galaxies.

(2) We developed new methods using near-infrared images and optical spectroscopy to measure gradients in the ages and characteristic luminosities of stars as a function of height above the mid-plane in dusty spiral-galaxy disks.

(3) We established a deeper understanding of the vertical structure of spiral disks: This allows us to model accurately the dynamical motions of their gas and stars to make reliable inferences about the amount of dark matter in spiral galaxies.

(4) We confirmed that spiral disks have relatively little mass in stars and gas (galaxies are dominated by dark matter in extended halos), and populations of stars have less mass for their luminosity than previously supposed. This result presents a challenge for our understsanding of stars and stellar populations, in particular indicating a more significant contribution from luminous, red stars than predicted by most models of stellar evolution.

(5) We successfully delivered and commissioned new, facility capabilities for two instruments on the WIYN 3.5m telescope, including narrow-band filters for a near-infrared camera, and fiber-optic bundles (integral field units, or IFUs) for 3D spectroscopy using the Bench Spectrograph (see the primary image).

6) We trained three students in science and technology, including the completion of one Ph.D. and job-placement in the private-sector in the area of advanced computer algorithms.
